_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: All Other Basic Inorganic Chemical Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
overpressurization, spring-loaded pressure relief valves would discharge the chlorine into a process tank of ferric chloride.  In the unlikely case of continued overpressurization, a rupture disk is utilized as an additional safety feature.  

Chlorine gas is piped from the railcars to the reaction vessels, where it reacts with ferrous chloride to form ferric chloride.  
 4    Worst-case release scenario.

The Clean Air Act risk management planning regulations require Midland to prepare a worst-case scenario consisting of the release of the entire contents of the largest vessel containing a regulated chemical in 10 minutes.  The largest chlorine-containing vessel is a rail car, whose content totals 90 tons (or 180,000 pounds).  Hence, the rate of release would be 90 tons/minute (18,000 pounds/minute.)  The USEPA provided software designated RMP*Comp (version 1.06) to assist in estimating the distance to a toxic endpoint, in the event of a release as describe herein.  The USEPA's RMP Off-site Consequence Analysis (OCA) Guidance provides tables for obtaining toxic endpoints and exhibit B-1 of this guidance document provides 0.0087 mg/L as the toxic endpoint for Chlorine.  

Worst-case scenario assumptions:

The contents of the rail car are released over a 10-minute period.
Ambient temperature = 77 degrees F.
Liquid chlorine is at 77 degrees F and 100 psig before the release.
Dense gas
10 minute release
18,000 pounds/minute
Urban Conditions
No passive mitigation.
Atmospheric Stability Class F 
Wind Speed of 1.5 meters per second.
The toxic endpoint for Chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L

The estimated distance to toxic endpoint is 14 miles using RMP*Comp (version 1.06).

5    Alternative Release scenario

On a hot day, a one inch diameter flexible line connecting the railcar to the rest of the process has a slow leak (not a complete break) from a 0.125 " diameter hole.  The line pressure is assumed to be 180 psig.  The chlorine sensor is located about 5 feet horizontally from the rail

car and about 15 feet below the hose, and should be activated almost immediately (less than 1 minute).  An operator goes to the control room and puts a respirator on within 9 minutes and has the leak isolated in another 10 minutes.  Total time for the chlorine leak is 20 minutes

Equation 11, from the OCA Guidance, yields a release rate of 3.92 pounds/minute for a  0.125 " diameter hole.  The amount of chlorine released is 78.4 pounds

Alternative release scenario assumptions:

The release situation is noted in approximately:     one minute
Operator summoned and puts on respirator:     nine minutes
Operator closes valve and isolates leak:    ten minutes
Total time of release:    20 minutes

Ambient temperature = 104 degrees F
Liquid chlorine is at 104 degrees F and 180 psig before the release.
Dense gas
20 minute release
3.92 pounds/minute
Urban Conditions
No passive mitigation.
Atmospheric Stability Class D
Wind speed of 3.0 meters/second
The toxic endpoint for Chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L

RMP*Comp yields a distance of less than 0.1 mile.  In order to obtain a more conservative value, the tables from the OCA Guidance were utilized.  
Table 16 of the OCA Guidance, using a release rate of 5 lb./min and toxic endpoint of 0.01 yields an estimated distance to toxic endpoint for this scenario of 0.19 miles. 

5    General accidental release prevention program

This facility has a strong commitment to the safe handling of chlorine and to minimizing the probability of an accidental release.  This is achieved through a combination of personnel training, process safety equipment and operating procedures.

6    Five-year accident history

This facility had an accidental chlorine release on October 21, 1995 and another on June 28, 1998.  Each release involved less than 10 pounds.  On each occasion, one employee was injured and there were no off-site injuries.  After the first occurrence, new equipment was purchased to replace that which failed and resulted in the release.  After the second occurren

ce, the standard operating procedures were revised and a tank level transmitter was installed to prevent the recurrence of the situation which had resulted in the release.

7    Emergency response program

The facility has a comprehensive emergency response program.  The Emergency Response Plan contains specific actions to be taken in response to an accidental release of chlorine, procedures to inform the public and health care information.  All employees working with chlorine are given 40 hour Hazwoper training with annual 8 hour refreshers.  This plan has been coordinated with the St. Louis City LEPC.  The telephone number for the LEPC is (314) 289-1900.

 8    Planned changes to improve safety

The planned changes (both procedural and equipment changes) were documented during and after the Process Hazard Analyses which were conducted on April 15 and 29, 1999.  A checklist is being utilized to track the progress of these changes and improvements.
